Review title: More gruesome but not as clever
Review_body: Mild spoilers will appear throughout!I'm a big fan of the original movie, and took the day off from work to see the premiere of its sequel.  After the first premonition scene and the first real death (which reminded me of Val Lewton's in the first) I was optimistic about this version.  After the promising start, though, things go downhill - the deaths are rushed but become the sole focus of the rest of the movie.  The characters are completely flat.  Plot is negligible.  I never really got a feel for the sequence like I did in the original, and continuity between the two films was lousy.  Granted, the first film botched up the "switched seats" order, but that film had a sense to it that I found lacking in the sequel.  Consider:  in the first film, Alex was without a pulse before being revived, yet he didn't end the cycle.  Why would the same circumstance work for Kimberly?  And what was Eugene's tie-in to Val Lewton again?  Did it make any sense at all?  Why did Rory see the hook vision?  OK, and I felt really cheated that Alex from the original was killed by a stupid brick.I enjoyed all the little tricks in the first movie - all the hidden 180's, the altered set and posters in the airport, the clever character names and in-jokes.  The sequel suffers from the departure of the original writing team, I think - they had a lot more fun with their film. The only thing that came close in this one was the magnetic refrigerator letters, but that was a bit too obvious for my tastes.As far as the deaths, I give them a mixed review.  The deaths in the hospital weren't nearly gory enough, the elevator incident looked extremely fake, the slice-and-dice was cool but the body fell wrong. I liked the first, the last, the pile-up, and the second impalement.In the first, I liked the fact that our character didn't die the way it LOOKED like he might - but it seemed like overkill when they used the same type of misdirection later, in the dentist's office and with the leaking gasoline.  There wasn't a single death that made me jump like Terry's in the first, in any case.I enjoyed the movie and it had its redeeming moments.  The ending and Rory's speech to Kimberly after he handed her his keys, plus Tony Todd's disappointingly brief appearance, were all pluses.  Overall, though, I prefer the original.  If you haven't seen the DVD version with the director's commentary, watch it and see how much truly clever stuff you missed.  The first film left me wondering about fate and inevitability: the second film made me wonder, after each death, only "OK, who's next and how?"

Review title: Not To Good, Not To Bad...
Review_body: A year after the events in the previous film, Final Destination 2 picks up with a brand new band of characters. In place of the horrific plane crash premonition, it hits us with something more common in all our lives, an enormous pile up on the highway. Once again a lone girl sees this disaster before it occurs and saves a this time random group of strangers from dying a most hideous death. The characters are a bit more diverse in this sequel but some of them feel dull and unreal more of you can tell that these people are actors. The script is still strong though, keeping those clever death scenes and tricks that I loved from the first film. Duely noted this film contains much more gore then it's predecessor. Making the fancy dress up that the first film had and striping it a bit to seem more like a slasher. Also unlike it's predecessor this one moves quite fast with the story. At some points making it feel rushed and a bit far fetched. Ami Larter returns to play Clear from the first film but with a completely new Sigorny Weaver style (as I like to call it) attitude being an expert on death's little Bobbi traps it sets. It introduces a new idea of how to stop the cycle of death and begins to fill in unanswered questions taking away the mystery of the first film. It did seem at first that this film would follow the same patter as the last and it does but the new ideas keep it refreshing enough to watch. It stick precariously close to the first films script as in character's personality's and clever little puns. But now on to the part that pulls most of it's fans in and thats the gore, I mentioned before there is a lot, and the deaths to accompany them are a bit more far fetched taking the great this could happen to you out from most of the scenes, but I feel all that is made up for in the incredible opening sequence of her premonition. Not a great sequel but certainly not a bad one.6/10

Review title: A Worthy Sequel (...but still a sequel!)
Review_body: If you liked the first one, you're in for a treat!  FD2 takes you on a bigger, wilder, and, of course, gorier ride than the first one.  I was hesitant at first with a new director and the absence of Devon Sawa, but I am pleased to report that the result is deserving of being a sequel to Final Destination; even though the title here doesn't fit as nicely without a plane crash - but what else would you call it?A good sequel gives you more of what you liked from the first one and new twists to keep you from saying, "been there, done that" or, "I should've stayed home and rented the first one."  FD2 has wonderful new twists that help it to rise above the typical sequel.  Yes, it's got more twisted fun that made FD such a kick, and it's done in an even more playful fashion. Best of all is how FD2 relates itself to FD.  That is what "made" the movie for me.  Where FD2 lacks is in its overall sense of foreboding, which really gave FD its charm.  Still, it is a nice complement to FD and shouldn't be missed for fans of the original.As for those who rip this movie to shreds based on acting/story, etc. This is not Oscar material here.  Who cares?  It's just a sick and twisted good time at the movies.

Review title: The most creative part about it was the deaths... and that's not saying much...

It felt like it was bordering on making fun of itself at many points, which would've saved the film a bit, but it didn't take the extra step to cross into that territory. The dialogue is completely laughable, and when it is good, isn't held in the spotlight as it should be. The spotlight of this movie, instead, is its gruesome gore, which at most times was portrayed in such a way as to almost make you chuckle at its lunacy.The actors who portray these poorly developed characters are faces you will forget as soon as you leave the theater. They are so bland and fit into such generalities that every actor will remind you of a friend or neighbor. The only saving grace is Ali Larter, who should be embarrassed to be a part of this wretched piece of trash. Bottom line; if you've seen the first, you've seen the second with added class and maturity.

The original is just as fresh as it was just under 3 years ago. I payed close attention to the signs of deaths imminent pounce and was ready for the second installment.So I made my way to the cinema and Grabbed a large CokeT and settled in for what I may call 'The movie event of the year.'.I was not let down!Final destination® made great use of the original plot without being corny although some scenes were (but isn't that what horror flicks are about?). The idea is that the 'survivors' in the original caused a ripple, in that because they didn't die, it prevented others from dying and now death is after those people. Review title: Death always waits upon your doorstep, looking for the right time to ring your doorbell...
Review_body: Although I watched the sequel before the original, I still found myself hanging on the edge of my seat, to the point where I actually fell off a couple of times. It is definitely a must-see, even if your not all that into horror flicks. My personal opinion is that the first movie outranks the second, mainly because they over-did the 'splatter-death' scenario from the original.My favorite character in the movie was Alex, not because he was the kick-butt psychic, but because of the way his character was portrayed. No normal human being would be able to stand up to that amount of pressure without having their mentality snap like a twig. I know some people are stronger than others, but my personal belief is that if you could see your death coming, then you would go crazy. The rest of the cast was very believable excluding Clear, who appeared to have a back story too-far-fetched for my personal tastes; father dying when she was ten and then her mother having left her soon afterwards? Not possible. She would have had to have been carted off to some kind of foster home, and we saw her all by her lonesome.

Even though the original was good, I think this movie is better. The fact that the deaths come "backwards" is a great idea, because usually in the premonitions, the main characters that you know the best die first. Now that it's backwards, we get to know the rest of the characters even better. It also returns a character. This makes it even better because we feel bad for the characters even worse, like a character who's son had died the same day (he was part of the premonition). I did feel extremely bad for the teacher in the first one, but I felt worse here. Especially for Clear, who was Alex's girlfriend in the first one. It also feels like Halloween 2, like it happened the day after (of course it takes place a year after in this movie) because there were some off screen deaths in the first one, like Terry's death and we finally see the body in this movie. This is a true sequel. You should watch this if you watched the first one.

Having seen the original "Final Destination", I was not expecting much from the sequel. But I had a free pass to a preview screening and a couple hours to kill and I felt like seeing a dumb movie. I had no idea what I was in for. Maybe it was because I saw the first FD on tape, without a jazzed audience, but I would swear that FD2 whips it's dad's butt up and down the dark alley they would invariably meet in. I haven't felt an audience engaged with a flick like that in years. Sure, a lot of people were jeering teen Anakin in Episode 2, and those same people were cheering Yoda when he went off. FD2 elicited a sustained series of groans, laughs, and screams that was a beauty to behold. Without giving anything away, those responses are well earned. FD2 crosses the line over and over, making you cringe and squirm and laugh because you know it's going to happen all over again. Anyone who has seen the trailer will not be surprised to find out that FD2 has one of the most over-the-top car crash sequences ever filmed. Having personally been in accidents numbering in the double-digits, I can say that this film made me more scared of automobiles than all of those accidents combined. "Final Destination 2" may just be another stupid movie with a lot of blood and guts, but it seems to know that and it just wants to have a good time. It sees the potential in the great idea in the original and plays it out the way it should be played. Go see it with a crowd on the weekend, and make sure you're in a rough hood where everyone is ready to see some of the grisliest deaths collected into one fast ride of a movie.

Review title: Great [Major, major, major spoilers. Don't read if you haven't seen the movie.]
Review_body: I though this film was great. Nowhere NEAR the first one, but still pretty good. The film begins with Kimberly Corman going on a trip with her friends, Dano, Frankie, and Shaina. Among the people on the highway are Kat, a business woman, Rory, a coke-addict, Evan, a lotto winner, Thomas Burke,a cop, Eugene, a substitute teacher, and Nora and Tim, a mother and son. Well, the various characters are driving down the highway when a logging truck in front of them accidentally drops its logs off the back of it. The first log crashes through the front window of the cop car, coming out the back with guts and blood all over it. Eugene's motorcycle spins out, flipping him off. He slides until he hits a log, but his motorcycle slides into him, splattering him. Suddenly, Rory's car flips out of control, flipping and turning until finally landing straight, only to be hit by an oncoming semi. Kat's SUV suddenly hits a log, flipping over and crushing her inside. Inside Nora and Tim's car, Tim's water bottles fall behind the break pedal, denying Nora the chance to break, eventually crashing them into a log. Suddenly, Evan's car spins out of control, slamming into a truck, exploding. Kim's SUV flips out of control and lands on it's side. She sees Evan burning alive in his car until the logging truck crashes through it, blowing it up completely. Then the truck crashes into Kimberly. Suddenly, Kimberly wakes up and sees all the signs of the crash. She parks her SUV across the on-ramp, keeping everyone off as the crash happens before their eyes. Suddenly, a semi crashes into Kim's SUV, killing all her friends. She survives because Burke pulls her out of the way. Afterwards, Evan is fixing himself dinner after throwing some spaghetti out the window, but his apartment starts on fire. He eventually gets out and falls off the escape ladder. He slips on the spaghetti and the ladder leg falls, stopping about 8 inches from his eye. He thinks he's safe, but then the ladder falls all the way, impaling him through the eye. Later, Tim is coming out of the dentist's office, but he goes and disturbs the pidgeons, which distract a construction worker, who drops a huge sheet of plate glass down which lands on Tim, squashing him to oblivion. Later, Nora gets her head caught in the elevator. As it goes up, her head gets chopped off. Later, Kat crashes her SUV, which sends a pole through her headrest. During this scene, Rory saves a farmer boy from getting hit by a news van. When the firemen are trying to get Kat out, they jam the jaws of life into the car, which deploys the airbag, impaling her head on the pole. She drops her cigarette, which ignites a trail of gas leading up to a news van, which explodes, propelling a barbed wire fence at Rory, which slices him into 3 parts which slide off each other. Later, Eugene's hospital room explodes when some oxygen leaks out and a plug sparks, killing him and Clear. At the end, the farmer boy dies when his barbecue explodes.In my opinion, this movie was pretty damn good.

Review title: A great sequel of campy, gory and great fun.
Review_body: Now, this is a sequel to 2000's surprise hit, and one of my favorite movies, `Final Destination'. I want to add how much I was expecting this movie (since Final Destination) and now I am happy to report that the movie was not a letdown and the three year wait was very much worth it.I will start off by mentioning what I did NOT like about this sizzle sequel, I know I shouldn't compare this with the prequel, but that way, you'll get better the idea. One of the many things I adored about the first movie was it's freaky and very scary atmosphere but where is it!? Not here! The movie is mostly shot in daytime, and that lowered a lot the sense of creepiness. One more thing I couldn't stand is that they turned this movie into another pop corn horror movie. It has way too many jokes I didn't appreciate all that much (the last frame comes to mind) and that mucho lowered the tension, which was another of the many things I adored about the prequel. The script had some flaws right there, maybe it is just me but maybe it didn't explain fully the idea of death's design, I didn't fully get it, but then again, maybe it was just me. The characters are much less developed as in the original, as being a bunch of strangers, you couldn't care less for most of them...they are all stereotyped and I was only waiting for most of them to die...(I kinda loved Nora actually) and add to that some extremely disposable side-characters (BBQ kid...lmao). As for the acting, I must say it's mostly convincing; if it's not the at times tacky dialogue pulling some characters down, it's mostly fine. I really didn't like Eugene I don't know what p***ed me off, if it washis characters or just HIM...I was waiting for the Angel of Death to do his thang on him.And guess what mistake the sequel did? The same as in Final Destination.a scene where some of the characters visiting the same creepy mortician (Tony Todd) we saw before, again, his character is not explored in any level, the scene again slowens the pace big time and is much more useless than in the original.Now, for the upside, this is by far the ballsiest R rated movie I have ever seen. I was extremely uncomfortable and was yelling like a maniac in the movie theater. I am not talking only about ball gripping tension, but the goriest, most 'out there' kill sequences I have ever seen. Remember how strong the run over kill was in the original Final Destination? That's nothing ok? Hear me out here. The kills are just amazingly strong and mind bending.awesome s***e. I also mucho enjoyed the fact of 'death' being again only a sadistic presence that we feel all around us. For some reason I felt it much more time than in the first one, there are thousands of accidents here. I also appreciated how they didn't just made 'another' Final Destination story, they also added a clear link between the events involving Flight 180 and this car pile up. Another great thing is that they also added some really cool new effect in death's design for this one, I will not give it away, but I really liked how it's not the same thing as Final Destination, the cool omens are still there, especially in the opening car pileup, which is definitely the harshest bit IMO. The Ellis man definitely knows his s***e, he has a great imagination and has BALLS, he also pulls tons of great enlarged shots, overhead shots, fluid camera movements, tension and silence. He has style!Final Destination 2 is a sequel that succeeds and fails in some levels. I will grade it a `8.5/10' for it's great entertainment and freak out value; Maybe it's not better than the original, but definitely doesn't embarrass it.

Review title: This Accident Is Most Realistic Yet,Best Movie I've Ever Seen
Review_body: This move is all about the real-life accidents and mishaps that could happen anywhere, anytime, to anybody. You think you're safe? Think again. This movie delivers with strong kills, a cast of unknowns(which is good, because you don't have to see pretty-boy Tom Cruise with a log through his face, which is good, because the rest of the cast doesn't have to to to compare to some big actor),and a plot that is just as scary. It starts with a group of people, 4 friends on a trip to Daytona Beach, a business woman, a biker, a druggie, a mother and son, and a cop. The driver of the truck holding the 4 friends, Kimberly Coreman,then sees "signs" along the road that hint of disaster, then disaster strikes. This has to be the most horrific/realistic car accident I've ever seen in my entire life. Like waking up, Kimberly then sees and hears all the signs that point out that an accident is in the works. She parks at the end of the on-ramp of the highway, and keeps everyone on it from being in the accident that follows soon thereafter. Sadly, her friends die tragically and brutally. What follows is a story about the survivors trying to save the life of an unborn child, and the lives of themselves. This flick just goes to show that accidents happen all the time, and at anytime in the day or night. You don't need creepy settings and ominous music to bring out the horror in this movie, because it's already there. Scary as hell kills and lots of fun is included. Definetly a must for the big horror fans. Have fun

Review title: Not as good as the first one, but gorier *minor spoilers*
Review_body: I saw this movie expecting to see another cleverly done psycho thriller, and I have to admit, it did pretty well. The death scenes were thrilling to watch, and they were very gory. But the acting was mediocre and the there wasn't much characterization, which makes it hard to mourn when you watch them meet their crimson ends.The disaster at the opening is awesome and memorable, much more intense than the plane crash in the first. Also, the one with the premonition is a girl, Kimberley Corman, who is already dealing with the death of her mother. Kim blocks the highway, also stopping several other people. They argue and think she's just a loon, until they see the pileup that death scheduled them to be in happen before their eyes.At first, they don't think twice that this wasn't their only encounter with the reaper. But soon one survivor was killed in a grisly accident involving a ladder(you can see the movie to find out what happened) when the second survivor meets his maker, she turns to Clear Rivers, the sole survivor from the first movie, for help.Even Clear's knowledge of death's design doesn't keep some more from dying, so they must figure out how to thwart death's rage, leaving blood and guts in it's wake. Towards the end of the movie, the whole series manages to take a turning point, and they make some surprising discoveries, including how Alex and the others getting off the plane unknowingly saved the pileup survivors.Overall, I'd have to say that despite having much more gory and intricate death scenes, this flick couldn't manage to live up to the original, perhaps that was because James Wong didn't direct it, but you'll be glad to know that Wong will be directing the third part of the series:).

Review title: Premonitions aren't all they're cracked up to be when Death comes back to get you.
Review_body: There's one major problem with this film: it needs Devon Sawa, and not just because he's more convincing as the subject of the premonitions, but he needs to be in this for the ending to work.***SPOILER***: At the end of Final Destination 1 Alex (Devon Sawa) cheats death by having his heart restarted after he gets electrocuted. Therefore he dies and comes back to life - the new life the film insists is necessary for cheating death - but gets a brick to the head anyway. (The writer's revenge perhaps?) What remains is a plot hole the size of Texas - clearly they expected him to return and wrote the script accordingly. When he didn't they switched in the character Clear for Alex as the survivor of the first film and gave the rest of his part to Michael Landes. I've nothing against Landes but how exactly does that work?The deaths are inventively gory (especially "Don't throw your pasta out the window" guy) if not always possible, but the plot is a nonsense.Take my advice: Skip 2 and go straight for 3. It will spoil nothing and make a lot more sense. Plus Kris Lemche, in homage to Christian Slater in 'Heathers', is a lot better value for amusing gore than any of the people on screen here.

Review title: Exactly what it tries to be.
Review_body: What I love about the Final Destination movies is that they don't try to hide the fact that they are gory trash, but instead they are almost proud of it. Unlike the other two Final Destination films and most horror films, it doesn't just revolve around a group of high school friends but takes people from all ages at random from society and puts them into this terrifying situation. I'm not generally a fan of horror movies, but somehow the Final Destination series has me as a fan.
